title: Vumatel seals deal with Investec | Telecoms & Technology
text:
Investec. Picture: MARTIN RHODES Related articles Investec pushes ahead with private equity deals Investec banking division expected to boost interims Related multimedia VIDEO: Johannesburg’s northern suburbs join the internet highway INDEPENDENT fibre broadband player Vumatel says it has sealed a deal with investment bank Investec.
Vumatel kick-started operations in 2014 when it connected upmarket Johannesburg suburb Parkhurst to high-speed fibre broadband.
Vumatel’s network is open access, which means customers can use an internet service provider of their choice.
Vumatel said that since 2014 its network had been expanded to another six suburbs while more than 25 residents associations had endorsed the company to lay fibre in their areas.
Investec had taken a minority share in the fibre provider, Vumatel said. The extent of the share had not been disclosed.
"This investment provides the business with the ability to connect up to 100 000 homes by 2016 and therefore further entrench Vumatel as the leading FTTH (fibre to the home) player in the market," Vumatel CEO Niel Schoeman said.
"This investment will allow us to deliver world-class connectivity, choice and superior customer service to every community that requests it," said Mr Schoeman.
Kobus Viljoen of Investec said Vumatel was setting the bar for the local fibre industry.
"Their commitment to creating affordable high-speed open access fibrehoods through focus on customer service will have a fundamental impact on the telecommunications industry," Mr Viljoen said.
Vumatel’s announcement of the Investec deal comes amid Telkom launching a new spin-off wholesale broadband division dubbed Openserve.
The division is set to supply wholesale fibre broadband access as well as metro ethernet, IP (internet protocol) Connect and SAIX (South African Internet eXchange) services. Openserve will also be a reseller of DSL internet services.
Openserve MD Alphonzo Samuels told Fin24 on Tuesday that 37,000 homes in SA already had access to the Telkom division’s fibre network with the company planning to connect a further 400,000 homes by the end of 2016.
